name: bcc - Bruce's Compiler
description: Bruce's Compiler - Bruce's C compiler is a simple C compiler that produces 8086 assembler for tiny/small memory models.

name: DJGPP
description: DJ Delorie's complete 32-bit C/C++ development environment for Intel 80386. Used for Quake.

name: GCC IA-16 toolchain
description: A 16-bit counterpart to DJGPP, a GCC-based toolchain for developing 16-bit (8086 to 80286, a.k.a. IA-16) DOS applications, currently maintained by TK Chia.

name: Open Watcom
description: Formerly commercial C/C++ development environment for 16- and 32-bit DOS and

name: Open Watcom V2
description: GitHub fork which is actively maintained and is

name: Turbo C 2.01
description: C IDE and compiler from Borland first released in 1987.

name: Turbo C++ 1.01
description: C++ IDE and compiler from Borland released in 1991.

name: DIV Games Studio 2
description: IDE to develop DOS games in 2d, mode 7 and 3d. Released in 1998.

name: T3X
description: A small, portable, procedural, block-structured, recursive, almost typeless, and to some degree object-oriented programming language by Nils M. Holm.

name: SmallerC
description: Portable self-hosting C compiler capable of producing executables for a number of platforms, including real and protected mode DOS programs, by Alexei A. Frounze.

name: Small-C Toolkit
description: A self-hosting Small-C Compiler Toolkit for DOS(8086) with: K&R C Compiler, Make, Linker, Assembler. First released in 1982 by Jim E. Hendrix.

name: 386MAX
description: Memory manager for DOS PCs with 386 or higher CPUs, released by Qualitas company in 1992. Source code was released in June 2022 on GitHub with GPL-3.0 license.

name: DOjS
description: JavaScript programming environment for MS-DOS, FreeDOS or any DOS-based Windows (like 95, 98, ME).

name: Lua for DOS
description: Online demo of Lua 5.3.5, compiled for MS-DOS on the Intel 80486 processor.

name: Micropython for FreeDOS
description: FreeDOS ad-hoc module for micropython.

name: perldos
description: Perl for DOS.

name: PythonD
description: Python for DOS, including multi-threading, networking and OpenGL.

name: The Life of MS-DOS by Brendan Byers
description: History of the DOS family including CP/M, Q-DOS/86-DOS, MS-DOS and PC-DOS. Article also includes a diagram of the timeline and family tree of DOS

name: 80x86 16-bit Compiling How-to by Alexei A. Frounze
description: 16-bit compilation tutorial for Borland/Turbo C/C++ and Open Watcom. Goes into depth of memory addressing and memory models.

name: 32bit DOS development with Open Watcom
description: 32-bit compilation tutorial for Open Watcom.

name: How to build DOS COM files with GCC by Chris Wellons
description: Build process of Chris Wellons's DOS Defender game using DJGPP. Goal was to create a 32-bit 80386 COM executable.

name: David Brackeen - 256-Color VGA Programming in C
description: 256-Color VGA Programming in C - Tutorial series to learn how to create graphics on DOS.

name: 640k Really is Enough for Anyone by Robert W. Oliver II
description: Short article about getting Turbo C running on FreeDOS and moving a pixel around.

name: Just keeping it real... old skool style - Scali's OpenBlog
description: Scali's OpenBlog - Blog post about Scali's journey of doing CGA, EGA and VGA programming.

name: Alex Russell's Dos Game Programming in C for Beginners
description: DOS game programming tutorial series including a primer on C, graphics, animation, input handling and collision detection. This series contains a tutorial for making buffered input handling. Last chapter contains full source code of a Break Out game on DOS.

name: The Artevida Game Programming Tutorials
description: Kevin Matz's almost book-length treatment of DOS system programming and VGA programming fundamentals using C/C++ and 80x86 assembly. Unfortunately it is incomplete and was abandoned since 2001.

name: PC Game Programmer's Encyclopedia
description: Collection of guides covering assembly, sound (Sound Blaster, Gravis UltraSound, PC Speaker, GameBlaster, Adlib), input, memory (EMS, XMS, DMA Transfers), PIT, VGA, SVGA, algorithms and file formats.

name: The Art of Demomaking by flipcode
description: Series from 1999 that introduces to graphics programming under DOS. The home site contains other late 90s/early 2000s game programming articles as well.

name: Programming MS-DOS with Power - DOS Programming, Undocumented DOS, and DOS Secrets
description: DOS Programming, Undocumented DOS, and DOS Secrets - System programming tutorials like disk handling, interrupts, inputs, sound, graphics.

name: Programmer's Heaven (InfoMagic)(March 1997) CD-ROM
description: Source code and files for the following topics: MS-DOS, networking, C, C++, Pascal, Visual Basic, Delphi, 3D, PC speaker, Soundblaster, Gravis Ultrasound, MIDI and many more.

name: bios.h header documentation by Digital Mars
description: API documentation for routines accessing BIOS operations directly (disk operations, BIOS keyboard, printer, time, memory, serial, interrupts).

name: Part 1
description: API documentation of functions for interfacing with the DOS operating system itself.

name: Ralph Brown's Interrupt List - HTML version
description: HTML version - List of every documented and undocumented interrupt call known, accessible through search, categories and interrupt numbers.

name: A look back at memory models in 16-bit MS-DOS
description: Raymond Chen's explanation of segmented memory, including near- and far pointers.

name: Values for standard video mode
description: List of all known video modes including BIOS interrupt numbers, text/pixel resolution, number of colors and video memory addresses.

name: Color Graphics Adapter: Notes
description: Document describing the hardware, memory map, register I/O and hardware clones of the IBM's original CGA.

name: VGA Hardware - OSDev wiki
description: OSDev wiki - Hardware guide for VGA cards that is also relevant for modern graphics cards including NVidia and ATI.

name: Graphical programming in Assembly (DOS)
description: A VGA programming tutorial that also shows the list of video modes (text, CGA, EGA, VGA, SVGA) in a table at the beginning.

name: VGA programming lessons
description: VGA programming tutorial series in Pascal and Assembly.

name: DOS Super VGA / VESA programming notes - by Myles
description: by Myles - VESA article with history at the beginning and short mention of the VESA VBE standard, but unfortunately the example codes aren't even available through Wayback Machine.

name: VESA Video Modes - OSDev wiki
description: OSDev wiki - Tutorial about querying VESA modes.

name: DJGPP VESA guide
description: Tutorial about querying VESA modes.

name: High-res high-speed VESA tutorial
description: Series of tutorials that include drawing pixels in VESA mode (protected or real).

name: C code sample for drawing in VESA 2.0 mode
description: Just code listing for drawing an ellipse in VESA mode.

name: Programming Sound Cards CD
description: A 1995 CD-ROM containing source code for Adlib, Gravis, Pro-Audio, Roland and Sound Blaster sound cards. The description for the folders on the CD-ROM is listed on the back of the CD-ROM case.

name: Making some noise with the PC speaker! - by Mark Feldman
description: by Mark Feldman - Very short tutorial on using the PIT for generating PC speaker frequency.

name: Frequencies of Musical Notes
description: Freqency table usable to parameterize the PC speaker.

name: Sound Programming with PC Speaker - Chapter 23 of A to Z of C
description: Chapter 23 of A to Z of C - PC speaker programming chapter of the "A to Z of C" book with source code.

name: Yamaha YM3812 (OPL2) sound chip Wikipedia article
description: Best starting point to learn about the OPL2 sound chip besides 8-bit guy's YouTube video.

name: The Ad Lib Music Synthesizer Card Programming Guide - by Tero Töttö
description: by Tero Töttö - Reference of OPL2 operations and registers.

name: Programmer's Guide to the Yamaha YMF 262/OPL3 FM Music Synthesizer
description: Reverse-engineered reference on OPL3.

name: Sound Blaster 16 Programming Document 3.5 by Ethan Brodsky
description: Programming the Sound Blaster 16 DSP CT1341 chip for recording and playback of digitized audio.

name: Soundblaster Programming Information v0.90
description: List of Sound Blaster models and registers.

name: Table of DOSBox cyclecounts according to processor types
description: A table for setting the appropriate DOSBox cycle count according to CPU types (IBM XT 88, 286, 386, 486, Pentium I, Pentium II). Comes handy when you are developing a DOS game and want to simulate the environment where you intend to execute it.

name: Game Engine Black Book: Wolfenstein 3D - by Fabien Sanglard
description: by Fabien Sanglard - Fabien Sanglard's walkthrough on the game engine architecture of id Software's Wolfenstein 3D on the IBM PC's hardware. Contains forewords by John Carcmack, Tom Hall and John Romero.

name: Game Engine Black Book: Doom - by Fabien Sanglard
description: by Fabien Sanglard - Fabien Sanglard's walkthrough on the game engine architecture of id Software's original Doom on Intel 486 system and game console ports. Contains forewords by John Carcmack, Dave Taylor and John Romero.

name: A to Z of C - a book on C/DOS programming by K. Joseph Wesley and R. Rajesh Jeba Anbiah
description: a book on C/DOS programming by K. Joseph Wesley and R. Rajesh Jeba Anbiah - Non-profit book on programming in C on DOS. DOS system programming starts from Part II.

name: Michael Abrash's Graphics Programming Black Book Special Edition
description: Collection of Michael Abrash's Dr. Dobb's Journal graphics programming articles and his work on the graphics subsystem of Quake (mirror).

name: Tricks of the Game-Programming Gurus - by Andre Lamothe, John Ratcliff and Denise Tyler
description: by Andre Lamothe, John Ratcliff and Denise Tyler - Comprehensive DOS game development book about starting out, creating 2D and basic 3D graphics, I/O and game algorithms.

name: Why DOS Was (and Is) a Thing - FreeDOS
description: FreeDOS - Historical talk starting from Unix, going through CPM, DOS 1.x, DOS 2.x, DOS 3.x, DOS 4.x, DOS 6.x, Windows 3.1, Windows 95 and ending with FreeDOS.

name: CGA Graphics - Not as bad as you thought! - by 8-bit Guy
description: Not as bad as you thought! - by 8-bit Guy - History and technical details about IBM's CGA system. Also describes 4-color RGBI and 16-color Composite modes.

name: How Oldschool Sound/Music worked - by 8-bit Guy
description: by 8-bit Guy - Video about PC speaker, FM synthesizers in NES and Commodore 64, Yamaha OPL chip in AdLib and Sound Blaster sound cards, PCM samples and MOD music.

name: Let's Code - MS DOS - by root42
description: MS DOS - by root42 - DOS programming tutorial series including VGA, SoundBlaster and VGA Mode X.

name: LGR - Evolution of PC Audio - As Told by Secret of Monkey Island
description: Evolution of PC Audio - As Told by Secret of Monkey Island - Comparison of playing the intro theme of Secret of Monkey Island through PC speaker, IBM PCjr/Tandy, AdLib, Game Blaster, Roland LAPC-1/MT-32, Gravis Ultrasound, Roland SCC-1 MIDI, SB16 Waveblaster/AWE32 and CD quality digital audio.

name: Porting Retro City Rampage to MS-DOS: From PS4 to 1.44MB Floppy
description: GDC talk. Brian Provinciano's presentation on porting Retro City Rampage from PlayStation 4 to DOS. Topics include optimization, using interrupts, timing, PC speaker sound, joystick, memory management and fixed-point math.

name: DOS Executables Explained - Nostalgia Nerd
description: Nostalgia Nerd - Video about DOS executable formats including .COM, .BAT and .EXE.

name: Why does DOS use 8.3 Filenames? - Nostalgia Nerd
description: Nostalgia Nerd - Video about the 8.3 limitation of filenames under DOS, FAT partitioning scheme, NTFS, VFAT, FatGo, and LFN.EXE.

name: What is DOS Protected Mode? / DOS Extenders- Nostalgia Nerd
description: Video about how PC memory looks like, conventional memory, extender memory and reasons for the need of DOS Protected Mode Interface (DPMI) and extenders like DOS/4GW.

name: MS-DOS has been Open-Sourced! We Build and Run it! - Dave's Garage
description: Dave's Garage - Former Microsoft employee David Plummer tells stories about development of MS-DOS and compiles MS-DOS 4.00 source code which has been open-sourced by Microsoft.

name: MS-DOS
description: GitHub repository of the original source code for MS-DOS v1.25, v2.0 and v4.0, open-sourced by Microsoft.

name: FreeDOS
description: FreeDOS is an open source DOS-compatible operating system that you can use to play classic DOS games, run legacy business software, or develop embedded systems. Any program that works on MS-DOS should also run on FreeDOS.

name: Allegro 4.2
description: Game development library for DOS, Windows and Linux.

name: LoveDOS
description: A framework for making 2D DOS games in Lua. API based on a subset of the LÖVE API.

name: DOS-VGA-Game
description: Marco A. Marrero's DOS VGA/hardware library implemented in assembly and Turbo Pascal.

name: DIGPAK sound drivers source code
description: Original source code for the DIGPAK sound drivers uploaded to GitHub by John W. Ratcliff.

name: DOS Defender
description: Christopher Wellons's x86 real mode DOS Asteroids clone created as an entry for Lundum Dare #31.

name: Dungeons of Noudar
description: First-person 2.5D dungeon-crawler on protected mode. Written in C++, includes software rendering, fixed point math, test coverage and sound (PC speaker, Adlib, OPL2LPT).

name: Emeritus Pong
description: Pong clone for DOS, Windows and Linux. Uses PC speaker for sound on DOS.

name: Floppy Bird
description: Flappy Bird clone written in 16 bit assembly. Not a DOS program, but a PC-Booter application instead (although it's also possible to build a COM executable for DOS).

name: George M. Tzoumas's collection of MS-DOS games and utilities
description: Turbo Pascal with few games in C and C++. Games include Nibbles, Connect Four, Ms Pacman clone and two arcade/platform games. One of them (ra2) was written using Allegro. Utilities are all written in Turbo Pascal, these include game system routines, file and disk utilities and terminate-and-stay-resident programs (TSR).

name: Gold Mine Run!
description: Platformer written in C using DJGPP.

name: Gridfighter 3D
description: '80s style arcade shooter written in Quickbasic. Also the very first known DOS game that supports Oculus Rift VR headset.

name: Hangman
description: Hangman clone written in Basic. Runs on at least 80286 processors and uses EGA graphics.

name: Magenta's Maze
description: 3D maze game using CGA graphics with algebra as theme.

name: Mario
description: Super Mario Bros clone written in Turbo Pascal.

name: NetHack
description: Descendant of the original NetHack rougelike game first released in 1987 available on multiple platforms.

name: Piskworks
description: Gomoku clone written in C. Works on DOS, ZX Spectrum, ZX81, ZX80, APPLE1, AS400 and Windows.

name: Plutonium Caverns
description: Overhead puzzle game written in C. Web version uses DOSBox ported to Emscripten to embed DOSBox into HTML5. However, the original executable is also downloadable and buildable with Open Watcom.

name: Ptakovina
description: Tetris clone written in C. Runs on DOS, Unix/Linux, ZX Spectrum and Windows.

name: sudoku86
description: Sudoku clone written in C. Runs on 8086/8088 CPU, uses CGA, MCGA or VGA graphics and uses a mouse.

name: Tetris
description: Tetris clone written in assembly.

name: Towers of Hanoi
description: Tower of Hanoi puzzle game written in Turbo Pascal. Originally released in 1996.

name: x86 pong
description: Text-mode Pong clone written in C. Runs as PC-Booter game and under DOS.

name: zmiy
description: Text-mode Snake clone written in C. Runs on 8086 DOS.

name: Cyberdogs
description: Top-down 2D shooter playing as a mercenary to earn money. Written in Turbo Pascal. Supports two player mode.

name: C-Dogs
description: Sequel to the original Cyberdogs. Ronny Wester, the original creator no longer maintains the website for the original C-Dogs, but multiple ports exists, including cdogs-sdl.

name: Abuse
description: Sci-fi side-scrolling platform game. Regarded as an innovative cult classic by most people. Supports SVGA mode up to 1280x1024 resolution. Written in C, the architecture includes a Lisp-scripting engine.

name: Beneath a Steel Sky
description: Point-and-click adventure game set in a dystopian future. Written in assembly.

name: Catacomb
description: 2D top-down shooter developed by Softdisk (later becoming id Software). Supports EGA and CGA graphics. Written in Turbo Pascal and assembly.

name: Catacomb 3D
description: First-person shooter in fantasy setting developed by Softdisk (later becoming id Software). Features pseudo-3D graphics with raycasting technique. Supports EGA graphics. Written in C and assembly. Compiled with Borland C++ 3.1.

name: Commander Keen in Keen Dreams
description: Side-scrolling platform game developed by id Software. Keen Dreams is the Commander Keen game created between Keen 3 and Keen 4 (often considered "Keen 3.5"), but was not widely released. Written in C and assembly.

name: Descent
description: First sci-fi FPS/space shooter to feature entirely true 3D graphics. Written in C and assembly.

name: Descent II
description: Sequel to Descent. Written in C and assembly.

name: Doom
description: Sci-fi FPS developed by id Software where you fight demons from hell on Mars. The DOS-specific code for Doom could not be published because of a dependency to the licensed DMX sound library, hence why it's cleaned up and only the Linux source is there. However, the Heretic and Hexen projects contain the original DOS code in a way where DMX-related code is removed.

name: Duke Nukem 3D
description: FPS developed by Apogee featuring the iconic character Duke Nukem. Written in C. Compiled with Watcom C/C++ 10.0.

name: Heretic
description: Dark fantasy FPS running on id Software's Doom engine.

name: Hexen: Beyond Heretic
description: Indirect sequel to Heretic.

name: Hovertank 3D
description: FPS developed by id Software. Features pseudo-3D graphics with raycasting technique, before Catacomb 3D and Wolfeinstein 3D. Written in C and assembly.

name: Quake
description: FPS developed by id Software set in a fully 3D world. Written in C. Compiled with DJGPP for DOS.

name: Quake Engine Code Review series
description: Code analysis by Fabien Sanglard.

name: Rise of the Triad: Dark War
description: FPS developed by Apogee. It was developed as a follow-up to Wolfenstein 3D, but was altered and became a standalone game instead. Uses a heavily modified Wolfenstein 3D engine. Written in C.

name: Sopwith
description: Side-scrolling shoot 'em up created by David L. Clark in 1984. The game involves piloting a Sopwith biplane, attempting to bomb enemy buildings while avoiding fire from enemy planes and various other obstacles.

name: MaiZure's Projects - Decoded: Sopwith
description: Decoded: Sopwith - Code analysis by MaiZure.

name: Wolfenstein 3D
description: FPS developed by id Software set in the Nazi German prison Castle Wolfenstein. Features pseudo-3D graphics with raycasting technique. Written in C and assembly.
